questiontext.text:
Exercise

Find the complex Fourier series of the periodic function: \[ f(t)=e^t \qquad -\pi < t < \pi \hspace{1cm} f(t+2\pi)=f(t)\]


 

\(f(t) = \displaystyle{\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty}\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
We have, since \(T=2\pi\), so \(\omega_0=1\) \[ \begin{align} c_n & =\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^\pi e^te^{-i nt} dt \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^\pi e^{(1- in)t}dt=\frac{1}{2\pi}\left[\frac{e^{(1- in)t}}{(1- in)}\right]_{-\pi}^\pi \\ &=\frac{1}{2\pi}\frac{1}{(1- in)}\left(e^{(1-in)\pi}-e^{-(1- in)\pi}\right) \end{align} \] Now simplify this as far as possible and write out the Fourier series: \[ e^{(1- in)\pi}=e^\pi\ e^{- in\pi}=e^\pi (\cos n\pi- i\sin n\pi)=e^\pi\cos n\pi \] \[ e^{-(1-in)\pi}=e^{-\pi}e^{ in\pi}=e^{-\pi}\cos n\pi \] Hence \( c_n=\dfrac{1}{2\pi}\dfrac{1}{(1- in)}(e^\pi-e^{-\pi})\cos n\pi=\dfrac{\sinh\pi}{\pi}\dfrac{(1+ in)}{(1+n^2)}\cos n\pi\).

Note that the coefficients \(c_n\) \(n=\pm 1,\pm 2,\ldots\) have both real and imaginary parts in this case as the function being expanded is neither even nor odd.

Also \( c_{-n}=\dfrac{\sinh \pi}{\pi}\dfrac{(1-in)}{(1+(-n)^2)}\cos (-n\pi)=\dfrac{\sinh \pi}{\pi}\dfrac{(1-in)}{(1+n^2)}\cos n\pi={c^*_n}\) as required.

This includes the constant term \(c_0=\dfrac{\sinh \pi}{\pi}.\) Hence the required Fourier series is \[ f(t)=\frac{\sinh \pi}{\pi}\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty (-1)^n\frac{(1+\text{ i}n)}{(1+n^2)} e^{\text{ i}nt}\qquad \text{ since}\quad \cos n\pi=(-1)^n \]
